content.protection: Two bolts on the route but you will also need some smaller cams to protect the crack.
content.location: In Aspen Alley just in front of a large flat boulder we would call the sundeck.

content.description: Up easy slab to a right-angling finger crack, providing some gear and a few awkward moves.  After the crack ends, the difficulty eases considerably.  End at the Zorro anchor.
content.protection: Small cams/stoppers up to 1.5".  Climb ends at 2-bolt anchor for Zorro.
content.location: (In Aspen Alley...) Located 15' left of Zorro, identify a right trending finger crack.  This is where you go.

content.description: Quality route.  Face climb up thin holds on the right face of a deep chimney, then right and up, following the bolt line.  Using the other side of the chimney makes the start easier.
content.protection: 5 bolts to 2-bolt anchor.  Small cams may be useful between the 1st and 2nd bolts.
content.location: About 100 ft. beyond (north of) Digital Dilemma.  Scramble up to the base of a chimney, and you will see bolts if you look for them.

content.description:
Appearing as if it might be quite trivial and suitable only for your aged auntie, it turns out to be somewhat challenging due to the unbalanced nature of the layback/staircase combo and small roof.   

  The larger story is that I was looking for easy climbs for Graduation Climb, and the staircase made it seem initially appealing.  Seconding, and second ascent, by Ron Morgan who claimed "5.10! The hardest climb I've ever attempted!"  Without further opinions, I'm calling it 5.9 for now.
content.protection: 2" for the initial layback, 3" for the roof, and small to 0.3 for the remainder face/thin crack climbing.  Use the fixed anchors for Digital Dilemma.
content.location: Left of Digital Dilemma, before the big slanted chimney/crack, you will find an obvious layback that seems to have a staircase built in for your feet.

content.protection: 4 bolts to 2 bolt anchor w/ chains.  Optional TCU placement in horizontal crack between bolts 3 and 4.
content.location: On the face to the right of the right facing corner just to the right of Digital Dilemma.  Lower or rap from anchors.

content.description: This is a very good face route with some exciting distance between bolts.  The crux section is in the first 20 feet and is very adequately protected by bolts. A little more run out at the top, but the climbing eases off quite a bit.  Bring some tcu's for the top.
content.protection: Bolts and tcu's at the top
content.location: Left end of Aspen Alley.  Starts just in front of a large pine tree.

content.description: Begin just to the left of the open book, go up about 6' and move into open book.  Ascend to overhang and work yourself out a little onto right face (the crux - at this point you achieve serendipity). Ascend again between overhang and face to a point above the overhang.  The climb now becomes a friction pitch with a few cracks here and there, then rock rolls over toward the anchors (65' elev. change, climb distance longer).
content.protection: Bring small and medium cams. Good settings in crack at back of open book and under overhang.  Enough settings on cracks in friction pitch.  Bring long sling to set rope 6' to 8' from anchor if you intend to rap down and belay second from bottom to lessen rope drag.
content.location: Serendipity starts out about 30' left of Digital Dilemma in an open book under a rounded overhang.  It ends at the Digital Dilemma chains.  Rap down from chains.

content.description: 10 feet left of Digital dilemma. Stiff climbing up to "tufa" with crux crossover to left after third bolt using deep two finger pocket.
content.protection: Small cams and RPs supplement 5 bolts. Share anchor with DD.

content.description: Very nice area to the West of Mosaic wall a few hundred yards.  Secluded little alley with nice aspens and several good bolted and mixed routes.  Routes face Southwest.
